[[Image:Ubuntu.png|right|thumb|Ubuntu 8.10<br /> (''Intrepid Ibex'')]]
â
Ubuntu 8.10 (''Intrepid Ibex''), released [[2008-10-30]],<ref name="intrepid_release">{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+milestone/ubuntu-8.10|title=Milestone ubuntu-8.10 for Ubuntu due 2008-10-30|accessdate=2008-04-28}}</ref> was Canonical's ninth and latest release of Ubuntu. It will be supported until April 2010. Ubuntu 8.10 has several new features including a new default theme, improvements to mobile computing and [[desktop scalability]], increased flexibility for Internet connectivity, an [[Ubuntu Live USB creator]], a guest account<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DesktopTeam/Specs/Intrepid/GuestAccount | title=Guest account specification | accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref>, an encrypted private directory for users<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/EncryptedPrivateDirectory | title=EncryptedPrivateDirectory}}</ref> and the inclusion of [[Dynamic Kernel Module Support]], a tool that allows kernel drivers to be automatically rebuilt when new kernels are released<ref>https://wiki.ubuntu.com/IntrepidIbex/TechnicalOverview</ref>.
+
Ubuntu 8.10 (''Intrepid Ibex''), released [[2008-10-30]],<ref name="intrepid_release">{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+milestone/ubuntu-8.10|title=Milestone ubuntu-8.10 for Ubuntu due 2008-10-30|accessdate=2008-04-28}}</ref> was Canonical's ninth and latest release of Ubuntu. It will be supported until April 2010. Ubuntu 8.10 has several new features including a new default theme, improvements to mobile computing and [[desktop scalability]], increased flexibility for Internet connectivity, an [[Ubuntu Live USB creator]], a guest account<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DesktopTeam/Specs/Intrepid/GuestAccount | title=Guest account specification | accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref>, an encrypted private directory for users<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/EncryptedPrivateDirectory | title=EncryptedPrivateDirectory}}</ref>, the inclusion of [[Dynamic Kernel Module Support]], a tool that allows kernel drivers to be automatically rebuilt when new kernels are released<ref>https://wiki.ubuntu.com/IntrepidIbex/TechnicalOverview</ref> and also a tool called "Cruft Remover", to clean up temporary/unecessary system files.
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 8.10 includes, among other programs, GIMP 2.6<ref>https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gimp</ref>, GNOME 2.24, Mozilla Firefox 3.0, OpenOffice.org 2.4<ref>https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/openoffice.org/+bug/267376</ref>, and Pidgin 2.5<ref name="pidgin" />. The server installation will include MySQL 5.0, PHP 5.2 and Python 2.5. Ubuntu 8.10 uses Linux 2.6.27 and X.Org 7.4. The fast-user-switch-applet has undergone major changes as well. It now replaces the logout button and can be used to change Pidgin or [[Empathy (software)|Empathy]] status.
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 8.10 includes, among other programs, GIMP 2.6<ref>https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gimp</ref>, GNOME 2.24, Mozilla Firefox 3.0, OpenOffice.org 2.4<ref>https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/openoffice.org/+bug/267376</ref>, and Pidgin 2.5<ref name="pidgin" />. The server installation will include MySQL 5.0, PHP 5.2 and Python 2.5. Ubuntu 8.10 uses Linux 2.6.27 and X.Org 7.4. The fast-user-switch-applet has undergone major changes as well. It now replaces the logout button and can be used to change Pidgin or [[Empathy (software)|Empathy]] status.
